story.storykicker: University of Rajasthan MA question paper asks question on BJP policy
story.storybody:
In an exam for course in MA in Rajasthan University, students were asked about the BJP policy. The question became controversy when two students protested but later took the exam and completed it.

(Read: AIBE 9 All India Bar Examination 2016: Results announced at allindiabarexamination.com )

About the question:

  • The question was asked in a paper of MA course, Rajasthani Language, Literature and Culture
  • This was question number 16 of the question paper
  • The exact question was: Discuss the ideology and policies of the Bharatiya Janata Party"

(Read: SRK's heartwarming speech at Dhirubhai Ambani International School will leave you awestruck )

Objections posed by the students:

  • The invigilator Dr. Gopal Sharan Gupta confirmed that the two students opposed the question who were then told to talk about it to the concerned authorities
  • Students protested saying that the question paper was prepared by someone with a political inclination towards the BJP
  • According to Dr.Gupta, who told the The Indian Express, the topic 'The present political party' is included in the syllabus

More on the controversy:

Krishna Gopal Shrama, director of Centre for Rajasthan Studies, remained unavailable to comment on the issue.

Archana Sharma, Congress spokesperson, said that the BJP government was trying to impose their ideology on students.

"They have already changed the syllabus to suit their icons and now this question proves that are bent on brainwashing students. At the university, too, the teachers want to please their masters," she added

Indian Youth Congress spokesperson, Sadiq Chauhan said that they will protest against the question paper

"The IYC opposes such divisive attempts. There should be no politicisation at places of education, but time and again, BJP has targeted educational institutes to push its ideology. We will protest against this question paper," he added.

JP Singhal, University Chancellor, said that he remained unaware of any such question.
